questions.text: A 42 year old male who exercised vigorously presents to the emergency department with profuse sweating, flushed skin, and rapid breathing. His body temperature is elevated, and he appears dehydrated. Which of the following types of glandular secretion primarily contributes to the cooling mechanism observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Merocrine 

Explanation:

Merocrine secretion involves the release of secretory products through exocytosis without loss of cellular material. Thermoregulation is primarily done by eccrine sweat glands which typically have merocrine secretion.

  • Eccrine sweat glands produce watery sweat by merocrine secretion directly onto the skin's surface. The sweat then evaporates, dissipating heat and aiding in the body's cooling.
  • Some other examples of merocrine secretion include salivary glands and goblet cells in the intestinal epithelium.

 Apocrine (Option B):

  • Apocrine secretion involves the release of cellular products along with portions of the cytoplasm.
  • Apocrine sweat glands present in the axilla, perineum, and groin regions secrete their secretion into hail follicles by apocrine mechanism and are primarily responsible for producing body odour.
  • The mammary gland (Modified apocrine gland) produces milk by apocrine secretion.

 

Holocrine (Option C):

  • Holocrine secretion involves the disintegration of entire cells filled with secretory products. Sebaceous glands in the skin utilize holocrine secretion to produce sebum, an oily substance that lubricates and waterproofs the skin and hair.

 

Endocrine (Option C):

  • Ductless glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream. They are involved in regulating various physiological processes and maintaining homeostasis within the the body.

questions.text: A 55 year old male with a 10-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with numbness and tingling sensation in the feet. He also reports no signs of sweating despite exposure to warm temperatures. Which of the following gland's functions is most likely to be impaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eccrine sweat glands

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario suggests diabetic peripheral neuropathy in which autonomic dysfunction results in impaired sweat production. It may be partial (hypohidrosis) or complete (anhidrosis).

  • Eccrine sweat glands are responsible for sweat production and thermoregulation.
  • They are located all over the body (more in palms and soles), open directly into the skin, and are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic nerves.
  • These glands have been active since childhood.
  • Disorders of eccrine sweat glands include Hyperhidrosis, Hypo/Anhydrosis, Miliaria, and Neutrophilic eccrine hidradenitis.

 

 Apocrine glands (Option B): 

  • The apocrine sweat glands are responsible for producing body odor, and they have no role in thermoregulation.
  • They are located in the axilla, groin, and perineum, open into the hair follicle above the sebaceous duct (pilosebaceous unit), and are innervated by adrenergic nerves.
  • They become active at puberty.
  • Disorders of Apocrine sweat glands include Bromhidrosis, Chromhidrosis, Fox Fordyce disease/ Apocrine miliaria, and Hidradenitis suppurativa.

Sebaceous glands (Option C):

  • These glands are responsible for the secretion of sebum into hair follicles that helps in moisturizing and lubricating the skin and hair.
  • Disorders of the sebaceous gland include Acne vulgaris, Rosacea, and Seborrheic dermatitis.

Ceruminous glands (Option D):

  • Ceruminous glands are modified sweat glands located in the external auditory canal.
  • They secrete a wax-like substance called cerumen, which helps moisturize and protect the ear canal from foreign particles.

questions.text: A 22 year old female presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of profuse sweating, mainly involving her palms and soles. She reports sweating occurs even in cool environments, significantly impacting her daily activities and social interactions. The starch-iodine test is positive. What is the first-line management in this condition?

choices.text: Removal or ablation of eccrine glands

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aluminium chloride hexahydrate

 

Explanation:

The given clinical condition is Hyperhidrosis, a disorder of eccrine sweat glands characterized by profuse sweating of palms and soles (palmoplantar hyperhidrosis) or axilla (axillary hyperhidrosis).

  • Minor's starch-iodine test is a non-invasive diagnostic test used to confirm the presence of hyperhidrosis in which skin is cleaned with povidone-iodine solution and then sprinkled with starch, the hyperhidrosis areas will be seen in blue‐black colour.
  • First-line management includes Aluminium chloride hexahydrate (Eccrine duct‐blocking agents) and Topical anticholinergics (glycopyrrolate).

Iontophoresis (Option B): It is second-line management for hyperhidrosis in which each hand is treated for 30 min by placing it into a bowl filled with tap water or anticholinergics drugs such as 0.05% glycopyrronium bromide solution and 20mA of direct current is passed.

 

Intradermal botulinum toxin (Option C): It is also second-line management for hyperhidrosis. It acts by prolonged blockade of neuronal acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction and in cholinergic autonomic neurons of eccrine sweat glands.

 

Removal or ablation of eccrine glands (Option D): It is a third-line management of hyperhidrosis and is done for axillary hyperhidrosis.

questions.text: A 32 year old man presents to the clinic with a rash on his neck and upper chest area after spending the day on his farm in hot and humid weather. He describes the rash as itchy and prickly. On examination, there are numerous small, erythematous papules present, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Miliaria rubra


Explanation:

Miliaria rubra (prickly heat or heat rash) arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts at the level of stratum spinosum in hot, humid conditions, resulting in sweat leakage into the epidermis.

It is characterized by small, red papules or vesicles accompanied by itching or a prickling sensation. It typically occurs in areas of the body prone to sweating and friction during hot and humid weather.

 

Miliaria crystallina (Option A)

Miliaria profunda (Option C)

Miliaria pustulosa (Option D)
  • Obstruction of eccrine sweat duct at the level of stratum corneum.
  • Seen in infants and are characterized by clear fluid thin vesicles that may rupture easily, leaving behind superficial peeling or desquamation.
  • Obstruction of eccrine sweat duct at Dermo-epidermal junction.
  • It is characterized by firm, flesh-coloured lesions or bumps beneath the skin's surface.
  • It follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra.

 
  • It is an infected variant of miliaria rubra by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by pustules or pus-filled lesions in addition to the typical features of miliaria rubra.

questions.text: A 42 year old man presents with complaints of foul-smelling body odour, particularly in his axillae, despite maintaining good hygiene practices. On examination, there are no visible skin lesions or signs of inflammation in the affected area. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bromohidrosis

 

Explanation:

Bromohidrosis, also known as malodor or osmidrosis, is a condition characterized by foul-smelling body odour caused by bacteria such as staphylococcus, micrococcus, corynebacterium, and propionibacterium breaking down apocrine secretion.

It often occurs in areas with a high density of apocrine glands, such as the axillae and groin.

 

Fox-Fordyce disease (Option A): Fox-Fordyce disease, also known as Apocrine miliaria, presents with multiple small, skin-coloured, or yellowish pruritic papules in areas with apocrine glands, such as the axillae, groin, perineum, and areolae of the breasts. 

 

 

Chromhidrosis (Option B): Chromhidrosis is the secretion of vividly coloured apocrine sweat, most commonly blue, yellow, or green, due to the secretion of lipofuscins in the apocrine sweat.

 

Hyperhidrosis (Option C): It is a disorder of eccrine sweat glands characterized by profuse watery sweating of the axilla or palms and soles. Eccrine sweat glands are primarily involved in thermoregulation.

questions.text: A 32 year old obese woman presents with multiple painful nodules and discharging sinuses in her axilla as shown in the image. She reports a history of similar lesions appearing and resolving intermittently over the past few years. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of this condition?

choices.text: Pruritic, scaly patches on the extremities
Painless nodules and the presence of comedones

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bridging scars indicate chronicity

Explanation:

The given clinical condition is diagnosed as Hidradenitis Suppurativa, which occurs due to the occlusion of hair follicles and apocrine glands.

  • It is characterized by recurrent, painful, deep‐seated nodules, abscesses, and multiple discharging sinuses in intertriginous areas.
  • It typically affects the anogenital region in men and the axillae in women.
  • Recurrent episodes of inflammation and tissue damage lead to the formation of bridging scars/rope scars, which indicate the chronicity of the disease.

Pruritic, scaly patches on the extremities (Option A): This is more indicative of conditions like eczema or psoriasis, which present with pruritic (itchy) and scaly patches on the extremities. Hidradenitis Suppurativa typically does not present with pruritic or scaly lesions.

 

Erythematous papules with central pustules on trunk (Option C): Disorders like acne vulgaris present with red erythematous papules and pustules, commonly seen on the face, chest, and back. Hidradenitis Suppurativa typically presents with nodules and abscesses in intertriginous areas rather than on the trunk.

 

Painless nodules and the presence of comedones (Option D): Hidradenitis Suppurativa is characterized by painful nodules and abscesses and is associated with polyporous comedones. Comedones are non-inflammatory lesions that result from the blockage of hair follicles by sebum and dead skin cells seen in Acne Vulgaris.

questions.text: A 25 year old man presents with small, painless papules on the inner surface of his lips. On examination, the papules are skin-coloured and located along the vermilion border. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fordyce spots

Explanation:

Fordyce spots are ectopic sebaceous glands that can occur around the vermilion border of the lips or within the oral mucosa. They present as small, painless papules and are typically asymptomatic.



 

These are also modified sebaceous glands but vary in their location.

Ectopic sebaceous glands are specialized sebaceous glands which open into the skin surface and are confined to particular locations, unlike the normal sebaceous glands which are primarily found in association with hair follicles on the skin throughout the body, with higher concentrations on the face, scalp, chest, and back.

questions.text: A 16 year old adolescent presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of multiple papules, pustules, and comedones on her face and upper back. On examination, there are numerous open and closed comedones, inflamed papules, and a few pustules distributed primarily on her forehead, nose, and cheeks, with some involvement of the upper back. Which of the following statements regarding the characteristics of this condition is correct?

choices.text: It primarily affects individuals over the age of 40 and is also seen in adolescents.
It is not influenced by hormonal factors.
Genetic predisposition is not a contributing factor.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Comedones are the hallmark lesion.

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical condition is diagnosed as Acne vulgaris, a chronic inflammatory skin condition associated with increased sebum production and the accumulation of dead skin cells within the follicles.
  • Comedones are clogged hair follicles (pores) that contain a mixture of oil (sebum) and dead skin cells. They are the hallmark lesions of acne vulgaris. They are non-inflammatory lesions and are of two types:

Open comedones (blackheads): These are follicles with a wider opening to the skin's surface and are not covered by the epidermis. When exposed to air, the keratin plug becomes oxidized and appears black.

Closed comedones (whiteheads): These are follicles with a narrower opening to the skin's surface and are covered by the epidermis. The accumulation of sebum and dead skin cells creates a white or flesh-coloured bump beneath the skin's surface.

It primarily affects individuals over the age of 40 and is also seen in adolescents (Option A): Acne vulgaris is typically seen in puberty and adolescence, not above the age of 40 years.

It is not influenced by hormonal factors (Option B): Hormonal fluctuations, particularly increased levels of androgens (such as testosterone), can stimulate sebaceous gland activity, leading to increased sebum production. They are often associated with hormonal conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH).

Genetic predisposition is not a contributing factor (Option D) : Genetic factors influence various aspects of acne development, including sebum production, follicular hyperkeratinization, and inflammatory responses. Thus, Genetic predisposition is a contributing factor to the development of acne vulgaris.

questions.text: A 21 year old female presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of persistent acne on her face. On examination, the lesions are as shown in the image below. Based on the grading of acne vulgaris, what is the most appropriate classification for this patient's acne, and what would be the initial treatment recommendation?

choices.text: Grade I acne vulgaris; topical retinoids
Grade II acne vulgaris; topical antibiotics + topical retinoids
Grade III acne vulgaris; oral antibiotics + topical retinoids
Grade IV acne vulgaris; intralesional corticosteroid injections

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade III acne vulgaris; oral antibiotics + topical retinoids

 

Explanation:

Grades

Lesions

Treatment

Grade I

Non-inflammatory lesions such as open (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads)

Topical retinoids

(Tretinoin, Adapalene)

Grade II

Non-inflammatory lesions (comedones) + inflammatory lesions such as papules and few pustules.

Topical retinoids + Topical antibiotics

Grade III

Multiple inflammatory papules and pustules ± nodules (moderate)

Topical retinoids + Oral antibiotics ± Benzoyl peroxide

Grade IV

Nodules + Cysts

(Most severe form)

Oral retinoids

(Isotretinoin)

questions.text: A 45 year old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of persistent redness, flushing, and occasional papules and pustules on her face. She reports that her symptoms worsen with sun exposure and spicy foods. On examination, diffuse erythema is present on the central face, predominantly on the cheeks shown in the image. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rosacea

 

Explanation:

Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by persistent diffuse erythema, facial flushing due to vascular hyper-reactivity, and the development of papules and pustules affecting the central face.

  • Triggers such as sun exposure, spicy foods, alcohol, and temperature extremes can exacerbate symptoms.
  • Four subtypes:

Subtype

Characteristics

A . Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea

Erythema and telangiectasia.

B. Papulopustular rosace

Papules and pustules.

C. Phymatous rosacea

Rhinophyma (thickening of the skin and enlargement of sebaceous glands on the nose).

D. Ocular rosacea

Affects the eyes and eyelids, causing symptoms such as dryness, burning, itching, foreign body sensation, redness, and sensitivity to light (photophobia).

 

 


 

 

Acne vulgaris (Option A): While acne vulgaris can also present with papules and pustules on the face, it typically involves comedones (open and closed) which are characteristically absent in Rosacea.

 

Lupus erythematosus (Option B): It encompasses a group of autoimmune diseases that can affect the skin and various organs. Cutaneous lupus erythematosus may present with facial erythema, but it typically has distinct features such as a butterfly rash (malar rash) over the cheeks and nose, which is different from the diffuse erythema seen in rosacea. Also, papules and pustules are not seen.


 

Atopic dermatitis (Option C): Atopic dermatitis presents with pruritic, erythematous papules and plaques, often with a flexural distribution, in individuals with a personal or family history of atopy. It does not typically present with persistent facial erythema and flushing which is characteristic of rosacea.
